title: How to Keep a Newborn Warm in Winter

steps.headline: Dress your newborn in 1 more layer than you are wearing.
steps.description: A good rule of thumb for dressing your newborn is to place them in 1 more layer than you are wearing. For example, if you are comfortable wearing a long sleeve shirt, then your newborn will probably need a long sleeved shirt and a cardigan.

steps.headline: Dress your newborn in warm clothes and outerwear for going outside.
steps.description: It is best to avoid taking your newborn outdoors in winter as much as possible. However, you may need to take your newborn outside to catch a bus or to walk to your destination with them. Your newborn will be more susceptible to the cold when you go outside with them. Make sure that you dress them in warm clothes, such as long sleeved fleece pajamas, and appropriate outerwear, such as a coat, hat, mittens, warm socks, and booties. Layer your baby’s clothing to ensure that they are warm enough and to make it easy to remove unneeded clothes when you are back inside with them. For example, you might dress your baby in a long sleeve onesie, a cardigan, and coat, plus a hat, mittens and warm socks and booties. Avoid bulky coats and sweater when you place your newborn into a car seat. Dress them in a few thin layers instead. Newborns and infants lose the most heat out of their heads. Make sure that the baby is wearing a warm hat whenever you leave the house.

steps.headline: Use sleep sacks instead of blankets.
steps.description: Babies can suffocate on loose blankets in their crib or bassinet, so do not place extra blankets in the crib or bassinet with your baby. Instead, use a sleep sack to keep your newborn warm at night. A sleep sack is like a wearable blanket for babies that goes right over your baby’s clothes and zips up in front. Sleep sacks come in different styles. For example, you can get sleep sacks that include Velcro swaddle wraps as well, which can help to increase your newborn’s sense of security. You can also get sleep sacks that are sleeveless and ones that have long sleeves. If you do not have a sleep sack, then you can also use a receiving blanket to swaddle your newborn, but make sure to keep the blanket under the level of their armpits.

steps.headline: Place a blanket over your baby’s legs and feet in the car seat.
steps.description: When you need to take your baby somewhere in their car seat, make sure to place a blanket over their legs and feet for extra warmth. This will help to protect your baby from the cold air as you take them to the car. Once your baby is in the car and the car has warmed up, you can remove the blanket if you think your baby is warm enough. If you have to be outside with your newborn for a few minutes to walk to the car or bus stop, then place a couple of heavy blankets over your newborn’s abdomen, legs, and feet. Avoid attachable sleeping bags for car seats. These were once popular accessories for keeping babies warm in cars, but they are no longer considered safe for babies.

steps.headline: Feel your baby’s skin to make sure they’re not too warm.
steps.description: Although you may be worried that your newborn will be too cold, it is also important to make sure your newborn does not become overheated. Watch your newborn for signs that they are too warm, such as skin that is flushed or reddish, warm to the touch, or sweaty. Rapid breathing is also an indication of overheating. Be aware that overheating is a risk factor for Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), so it is crucial to avoid making your baby too warm.

steps.headline: Set the thermostat to between 68 °F (20 °C) to 72 °F (22 °C).
steps.description: Keeping the temperature at a comfortable level in your home is an important part of keeping your newborn warm. Between 68 °F (20 °C) to 72 °F (22 °C) is an optimal range for your home when you have a newborn.

steps.headline: Eliminate drafts around your newborn’s crib and changing table.
steps.description: Drafty areas of your home may cause your newborn to become chilled. Keep your newborn away from drafty windows and doorways, especially when they are sleeping or getting a diaper change. To eliminate drafts around doorways, try placing a rolled up towel or blanket on the floor in front of the door. For drafty windows, get some heavy curtains or cover your windows with plastic during the winter.

steps.headline: Keep the environment extra warm when bathing your newborn.
steps.description: It is especially important to keep your newborn warm when you are bathing them. Newborns lose more heat when they are wet. Turn the thermostat up or use a space heater to make it warmer in your home when you are bathing your newborn. If your home tends to be cold in winter and you don’t have a way to warm it up, then give your newborn a sponge bath and immediately dry the areas you wash.

steps.headline: Provide kangaroo care to your newborn.
steps.description: Skin to skin contact, also known as kangaroo care, is an excellent way to bond with your newborn, increase their sense of security, and keep your baby warm. You can provide kangaroo care by holding your newborn against your bare chest. Take off your shirt and remove your newborn’s clothing except for their diaper. Then, snuggle your newborn against your chest with a receiving blanket over both of you. The body heat you provide will keep your newborn warm.

steps.headline: Use a wrap carrier to hold your newborn.
steps.description: Wrap carriers also use body heat to keep your newborn warm because your newborn will be snuggled right up against your body while in the wrap. You can get a wrap carrier, such as a K'tan or Boba wrap, and use it to hold your newborn. Make sure to follow the instructions for how to put on the wrap and how to place your newborn in it. Keep in mind that the wrap counts as 1 layer of clothing on your baby. For example, if your baby is wearing a cotton pajama, and you place your baby in a wrap carrier, then it is like your baby is wearing 2 pairs of pajamas.

steps.headline: Breastfeed your baby if possible.
steps.description: Breastfeeding is another great way to keep your newborn warm while also feeding them. The warmth from the milk and the warmth of your body while you hold and feed your newborn will help to keep them warm. If you are able to breastfeed, do so. If you do not breastfeed, you can still keep your baby warm during feedings by holding them close to your body.
